title: How CLL Is Different From Other Types of Leukemia

content: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) starts in bone marrow, the soft inner part of your bones. There are some key differences that set CLL apart from other types of leukemia, such as ALL (acute lymphocytic leukemia), AML (acute myeloid leukemia), and CML (chronic myeloid leukemia).

content_blocks.text: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) starts in bone marrow, the soft inner part of your bones. There are some key differences that set CLL apart from other types of leukemia, such as ALL (acute lymphocytic leukemia), AML (acute myeloid leukemia), and CML (chronic myeloid leukemia).

sections.heading: Who Gets It
content: CLL is the most common leukemia in adults. Most people get diagnosed in their 60s and 70s. As you age, your risk increases. Other leukemia types, such ALL and AML, mainly happen in childhood. Kids usually don’t get slow-growing forms of leukemia. Most people with CLL live much longer than people with some other types of cancer or leukemia.

content_blocks.text: CLL is the most common leukemia in adults. Most people get diagnosed in their 60s and 70s. As you age, your risk increases. Other leukemia types, such ALL and AML, mainly happen in childhood. Kids usually don’t get slow-growing forms of leukemia. Most people with CLL live much longer than people with some other types of cancer or leukemia.

sections.heading: Where It Starts
content: CLL and ALL begin in the bone marrow, where blood cells are usually made. Specifically, it starts in a type of bone marrow cell called lymphocytes. (That’s what the first “L” in CLL and ALL refers to.) Lymphocytes become a type of white blood cell, which helps your body fight off infections. But with CLL, your lymphocytes grow out of control. Blood tests often show a higher number of white blood cells or lymphocytes than normal. You’ll likely get more tests to find out if this is leukemia. Two other types of leukemia — acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) — start in myeloid stem cells found in your bone marrow. This type of stem cell can change into: White blood cells like monocytes, granulocytes, and neutrophils Red blood cells, which carry oxygen Platelets, which form clots to help stop bleeding

(That’s what the first “L” in CLL and ALL refers to.) Lymphocytes become a type of white blood cell, which helps your body fight off infections. But with CLL, your lymphocytes grow out of control. Blood tests often show a higher number of white blood cells or lymphocytes than normal. You’ll likely get more tests to find out if this is leukemia. Two other types of leukemia — acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) — start in myeloid stem cells found in your bone marrow. This type of stem cell can change into: White blood cells like monocytes, granulocytes, and neutrophils Red blood cells, which carry oxygen Platelets, which form clots to help stop bleeding

sections.heading: How Fast Cancer Cells Grow
content: The “C” in CLL stands for chronic. This means the cancer usually grows and spreads slowly, although CLL can also grow more quickly. In contrast, types of leukemia that have “acute” in their name (acute lymphocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia) grow much faster than most chronic leukemias. People with these types are usually very sick and need treatment right away. If, like most people with CLL, you have the slow-growing kind, you might not notice any symptoms for years. A routine blood test might be the first clue that something’s wrong. You may not need treatment right away. Your doctor will closely follow your health, of course. Whether you need to start treatment depends on your: Symptoms Test results Stage (0 through IV) of your disease. Doctors can test for common and uncommon proteins on the surface of CLL cells. The test answers can help diagnose and treat your cancer, as well as check on the prognosis (how the condition may affect you).

sources: American Cancer Society: “Leukemia,” “If You Have Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL),” “What Is Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia?”
meta_description: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is the most common leukemia diagnosed in adults. What sets CLL apart from other leukemia types include where it starts and how fast it usually grows.
